topics.title: Introduction to Band Stop Filter
topics.description: Definition and importance of band stop filters
topics.coverage_text:
Hey friends, welcome to the YouTube channel all about electronics.
So, in this video, we will learn about the bandpass and the penstop filter.
So in the last couple of videos, we had seen that how to design the active as well as the
passive low pass and the high pass filter using the resistor and the capacitor.
And we had seen that this low pass filter passes the low frequency components from the
input signal while the high pass filter passes the high frequency components from the input
signal.
But sometimes in some applications, we are only interested in the particular band of frequencies.
So, for such applications, we can use this bandpass filter.
So as you can see, this bandpass filter passes only certain band of frequencies.
And it rejects all the frequencies which is outside of this band.
So now there are many ways in which we can design this bandpass filter.
And one of the way is to design this bandpass filter using the series RLC circuit.
And particularly, when you take the output across this resistor, then the response of this circuit

topics.title: Finding the Cutoff Frequency
topics.description: Calculating the cutoff frequency for high-pass and low-pass filters
topics.coverage_text:
will be very similar to the response of this bandpass filter.
And we have already seen this in the earlier videos of a series resonance in the RLC circuit.
So for more information, you can check that video.
But in this video, we will learn how to design this bandpass filter just by using this high
pass and the low pass filter.
So, just by cascading this high pass filter and the low pass filter, we can design this
bandpass filter.
So now let's understand how this combination will act as a bandpass filter.
So let's say, we have one low pass filter which is having a cutoff frequency let's say
FC1.
And let's say we have one high pass filter which is having a cutoff frequency of FC2.
Now whenever we cascade this high pass and the low pass filter, then we will get an overlapping
region between the individual responses of this high pass and the low pass filter.
And this overlapping region will act as a bandpass filter.
So in this way, just by cascading this high pass and the low pass filter, we can design
this bandpass filter.
So now if you see the frequency response of this bandpass filter, you will immediately notice
that this filter will have two cutoff frequencies.
The one is known as the lower cutoff frequency and the other frequency is known as the higher
cutoff frequency.
And beyond these cutoff frequencies, the roll-off will be at the rate of 20 dB per decade.
And that is particularly true when you design this bandpass filter just by cascading the first
order high pass and the low pass filter.
Now, the frequency difference between this cutoff frequency is known as the bandwidth of
this bandpass filter.
So now let's see some of the parameters which defines this bandpass filter.
So as I said earlier, the difference between the two cutoff frequencies is known as the
bandwidth of this filter.
And the geometric mean of these two cutoff frequencies is known as the center frequency of this bandpass
filter.
So, for this frequency response, the center frequency will be somewhere around here.

topics.title: Cutoff Frequency of High-Pass Filter
topics.description: Calculating the cutoff frequency for a specific resistor and capacitor value
topics.coverage_text:
So that will be the center frequency of this bandpass filter.
And if we see the phase response of this bandpass filter, then the phase response will look
like this.
So as you can see, at zero frequency, the output will lead the input by a 90 degree.
And as we move toward the center frequency, the phase difference will gradually reduce.
So now, when we start moving away from this center frequency, then the output will start
lagging the input signal.
And at f is equal to infinity, the output will lag the input by a 90 degree.
Alright, so now as we have seen the phase and the frequency response of this bandpass filter,
so let's take one example based on this bandpass filter.

topics.title: Cutoff Frequency of Low-Pass Filter
topics.description: Calculating the cutoff frequency for a specific resistor and capacitor value
topics.coverage_text:
So in this example, we have given this filter and we have been asked to find the bandwidth of
this given filter.
So as you can see in this example, the high pass filter and the low pass filter are cascaded.
And using this cascade connection, the bandpass filter has been designed.
So, to find the bandwidth of this filter, first of all let's find the cutoff frequency of
this individual high pass and the low pass filter.
So, let's first of all find the cutoff frequency of this high pass filter.
And let's assume that the cutoff frequency of this high pass filter is fc1 and the cutoff
frequency of this low pass filter is fc2.
Now, we know that the cutoff frequency of this high pass filter can be given by the equation

topics.title: Stop Band Calculation
topics.description: Determining the stop band for the high-pass and low-pass filters
topics.coverage_text:
1dr by 2π into RC.
So now, if we put the value of this resistor and capacitor, then we will find the cutoff frequency
of this low pass filter.
So, let's see, the cutoff frequency of this low pass filter will be around 10.61 kHz.
So in this way, we have found this cutoff frequency of this high pass filter as 10.61 kHz.
So similarly, now let's find the cutoff frequency of this low pass filter.
So again, the cutoff frequency of this low pass filter can be given by the equation 1dr by
2π into RC.
And if we put the value of this resistor and capacitor, then the cutoff frequency of this
low pass filter will be 106.1 kHz.
So in this way, we have found the cutoff frequency of this low pass filter as 106.1 kHz.

topics.title: Filter Order
topics.description: Classifying the filter as second-order based on its transfer function
topics.coverage_text:
So now, the bandwidth of this band pass filter can be defined as the difference between these
two cutoff frequencies.
So the bandwidth of this band pass filter will be FC2-FC1 that is equal to 106.1-10.61 kHz.
And that is nothing but 95.5 kHz.
So roughly we can say that this band pass filter having a bandwidth of 100 kHz.
So in this example, now if you see here, we have designed this band pass filter just by
cascading this passive, high pass and the low pass filter.
And as this filter is designed using this passive components, so the actual values of this cutoff
frequencies will be slightly different from the designed values.
And the reason is that the input impedance of this high pass filter will affect the cutoff
frequency of this low pass filter.
So, in this way, because of this cascade connection of this passive filters, the design frequencies

topics.title: Conclusion and Next Steps
topics.description: Summarizing the video and introducing higher-order filters
topics.coverage_text:
and the actual cutoff frequencies will be slightly different.
And to avoid that, we can isolate the two stages by using the buffer.
So, in the last video, we have already seen that, by using this op-amp as a buffer, we
can isolate the different stages of this filter.
So instead of using this passive low pass and the high pass filter, we can use this active
low pass and the high pass filter.
And just by cascading these two active low pass and the high pass filter, we can design
this band pass filter.
And by using this op-amp as a buffer, we can isolate the two different stages as well.
And suppose if we want the gain from this active filter, then we can configure this op-amp either
in a inverting or a non-inverting configuration.
So in this way, not only we can isolate the two different stages, but we can also achieve
the gain out of this filter.
So now like we have seen this band pass filter, let's see one more filter whose response is
exactly opposite to that of this band pass filter.
So this filter is known as the band stop filter or a band reject filter.
